title: CLOUDY CORNEA AND LEUCOCORIA

sections.title: Clinical Urgency
content: Opacification of the cornea, lens, or posterior structures is usually associated with poor vision and may indicate serious, even life-threatening, pathology (see Table 18.17).
All patients with leucocoria must be assessed for the possibility of retinoblastoma.

sections.title: Leucocoria Differential Diagnosis
content: Refer to Table 18.18 for detailed differentiation

rows: Forceps injury may induce ruptures in Descemet’s membrane (usually unilateral with vertical break)
Corneal oedema, iIOP, watering, injection ± anterior segment/angle abnormalities, haab striae
Photophobia, watering, circumlimbal injection, corneal infiltrate ± epithelial defect ± AC activity
Clinical pattern varies but may be evident from birth (e.g. congenital hereditary endothelial dysfunction)
Bilateral corneal clouding with systemic abnormalities in some mucopolysaccharidoses
Congenital, usually bilateral central opacities, adhesions to iris or lens
Bilateral (often asymmetric), peripheral/total opacification with vascularization ± other corneal/angle anomalies
Solid white mass that may involve peripheral cornea; rarely bilateral and 360° round limbi
Peripheral opacity due to anteriorly displaced Schwalbe’s line ± other angle/ocular abnormalities
Lens opacity: stationary or progressive; isolated or associated with other ocular/systemic abnormalities
Variable persistence of fetal vasculature/hyaloid remnants; often microphthalmic; usually unilateral
Fibrous membrane behind the lens arising from the ciliary body due to chronic intraocular inflammation
Retinal mass of endophytic, exophytic, or infiltrating type; may spread to anterior segment, orbit, etc.
Developmental defect resulting in variably sized defect involving disc, choroid, and retina
Early cessation of peripheral retinal vascularization due to prematurity causes, fibrovascular proliferation
Avascular peripheral retina, retinal folds and detachment, peripheral retinal exudates
Abnormal peripheral retinal vascularization due to inherited defect causes ROP-like picture
Grey vascularized mass from extensive gliosis (e.g. Norrie disease, Patau syndrome, etc.)
